results.title: Ukrainian dance
results.creator_credit: Laura Boulton and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Music and dances are performed by the Ukrainian Canadians of Manitoba, largest Slavonic group in Canada. The first part of the film shows the customs and religious ceremonies at holidays for these people. Four dances comprise the second part of the film: the Bird Dance, the Cossack Dance, the Cossack War Dance, and the Catherina Dance.

results.title: Ugetsu Monogatari = Tales of the pale and silvery moon after the rain
results.creator_credit: Kenji Mizoguchi, Masaichi Nagata and Daiei Motion Picture Company
results.brief_description: An unforgettably haunting film in every sense, this film is adapted from two stories in a collection of ghostly tales by the eighteenth-century writer Akinari Ueda, and Guy De Maupassant. Genjuro, a poor potter trying to make a living in a war-torn medieval village, is lured away from his devoted wife and young son by the mysterious Lady Wasaka who turns out to be a ghost. When Genjuro returns home repentant, his wife, too, has become a ghost after being murdered by stragglers weary from battle. Mizoguchi’s depiction of the past is vivid, richly detailed but not in the least romantic. For all its panache, the age he shows us is one of cruelty, oppression, and often appalling casual brutality. Cast includes Masayuki Mori, Kinuyo Tanaka and Machiko Kyo. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Canada: Toronto and Niagara Falls
results.creator_credit: Carmen Bourquardez and Hughes Leisure Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Travel, Travel”.
Visits the museums, malls and churches of Toronto and features what to see as a tourist in this city which mixes the old with the new. A religious group the Mennonites, are encountered and later at Toronto’s own Oktoberfest, we join in with the celebration. Journeying to Stratford, we go backstage at the Festival Theatre. The spectacular Niagara Falls and some of the neighbouring attractions are also visited on this journey.

results.title: Witness [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Edward S. Feldman and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Peter Weir’s captivating American film debut is presented as a white knuckle mystery thriller, collision of cultures and a sensual romance. An Amish boy witnesses a drug-related murder and with his mother (Kelly McGillis) and a wounded cop (Harrison Ford), takes refuge in the sheltered Amish community. Violence comes to “peacelands” in a film of stark contrasts, delicate subtleties and surprising humour. Note how the widow blooms under the cop’s attentions. Ford has never been better, portraying a hero real enough to show fear when faced with both barrels of a shotgun. Cast includes Josef Sommer, Lukas Haas, Jan Rubes, Alexander Godunov, Patti Lupone, Danny Glover and Brent Jennings.

results.title: Greece: North and South; Athens
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Travel, Travel”.
This travel video begins in the Halkidiki region of northern Greece, site of centuries-old monasteries. From Halkidiki we move to the city of Thessaloniki which is full of the influence of not only Greek and Roman civilisation but also Venetian and Arab. The travels continue south to the coastal regions of the Pelyponnese. In the second part we explore Athens: including the taverns of Plaka, the flea markets in Monasteraki, the original Olympic Stadium and , of-course, the Parthenon and the Acropolis.

results.title: What is a Jew to you?
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Michael Rubetzki and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Documentary film maker Aviva Ziegler turns the camera on herself in this personal exploration of what being Jewish means to her and why she calls herself a Jew despite not maintaining a Jewish lifestyle. She speaks with family and friends about growing up in Sydney, commenting on religious practices from the past, pondering why her brother has maintained his Jewish heritage and Aviva has gravitated towards other groups in society. Aviva reaches the conclusion that the effects of the Holocaust have made her feel Jewish, regardless of whether she is living within the tradition or not.

results.title: What in the world is water
results.creator_credit: Martin Defallo, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Water is a willing worker; shaping the land, shifting earth or rock, carrying the food by which plants survive and so supporting other forms of life. Water is also beautiful: raindrops pelting the earth, the mighty cataract of Niagara.
